questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with complaints of fever, severe earache, vomiting, and reduced hearing. Otoscopic examination reveals a bulging, red tympanic membrane with loss of landmarks, and a yellow spot is visible. What stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM) is this child most likely in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stage of suppuration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The suppurative stage of ASOM is marked by bulging tympanic membrane, yellow spot, severe earache, and high fever , indicating accumulation of pus in the middle ear.
  • ➤ suppurative stage of ASOM
  • ➤ bulging tympanic membrane, yellow spot, severe earache, and high fever
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the physiological basis for body equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture

options.label: B
options.text: The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs

options.label: C
options.text: Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance

questions.correct_answer: C. Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Equilibrium is maintained by a bilateral vestibular push-pull system integrated with visual and somatosensory input, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal responses.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18

questions.text: A patient presented with a sudden decrease in vision in right eye. While assessing his pupils, when light was shone in the left eye, both pupils constricted and when light was shone in the right eye, both pupils dilated. The likely abnormality is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marcus Gunn pupil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Wernicke’s Pupil: if a very bright but small beam of light such as that produced by a slit lamp is shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient with damage to the optic chiasm or optic tract and then is shined on the seeing hemiretina, it is possible to see that the pupil reacts better when the light shines on the seeing hemiretina than when it shines on the nonseeing retina.
  • • Option A.
  • • Wernicke’s Pupil:
  • • bright
  • • small beam of light
  • • shined on the nonseeing hemiretina of a patient
  • • damage to the optic chiasm
  • • optic tract
  • • Option B . Horner’s Pupil: This is a part of Horner's syndrome , which includes ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the affected side . The pupil in Horner's syndrome is smaller on the affected side but reacts normally to light and accommodation. This is not consistent with the described findings.
  • • Option B
  • • Horner’s Pupil:
  • • part of Horner's syndrome
  • • includes ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the affected side
  • • Option D . Adie’s Pupil: This involves a tonic pupil that is larger than the other and reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response . It's usually caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye. This does not match the clinical picture of an RAPD.
  • • Option D
  • • Adie’s Pupil:
  • • tonic pupil that is larger than the other and reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient presenting with a sudden decrease in vision in one eye and an observed pupil response where shining light in the unaffected eye causes both pupils to constrict , but shining it in the affected eye causes both to dilate, the likely diagnosis is a Marcus Gunn pupil (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), indicative of asymmetric optic nerve dysfunction.
  • ➤ patient presenting with a sudden decrease in vision in one eye
  • ➤ observed pupil response where shining light in the unaffected eye causes both pupils to constrict
  • ➤ Marcus Gunn pupil
  • ➤ REF : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 312
  • ➤ REF : KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5 TH EDITION pg.no: 312

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a one-week history of itching and fullness in her right ear. She reports no pain but mentions a slight hearing reduction. She has a history of swimming regularly. On examination, the external auditory canal is erythematous and has black-headed filamentous debris. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Which microorganism is most commonly responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillus Niger

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergillus niger is the most common cause of otomycosis, a fungal infection of the external auditory canal. It presents with itching, ear fullness, and black-headed filamentous fungal debris, particularly in individuals with frequent swimming exposure. Management includes aural toilet and topical antifungal therapy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 51.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with acute onset of right-sided facial paralysis, severe ear pain, and a vesicular rash in his right ear. He also reports some hearing loss and vertigo on the same side. His past medical history is significant for chickenpox in childhood. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ramsay Hunt Syndrome (Herpes Zoster Oticus) is caused by reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and a vesicular rash in the ear or oral mucosa. It can also involve the vestibulocochlear nerve, causing hearing loss and vertigo. Early treatment with antivirals and corticosteroids improves outcomes.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 52.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with acute onset of severe ear pain and hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals multiple blisters on the tympanic membrane. This presentation is most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Myringitis bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Myringitis bullosa is a condition characterized by the presence of vesicles or blisters on the tympanic membrane, often associated with severe ear pain and temporary hearing loss, and commonly seen in the context of viral infections.

  • ➤ presence of vesicles

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of a persistent, slowly enlarging mass in his right nostril over the past year. He reports occasional epistaxis and a sensation of nasal obstruction. The patient is a farmer and recalls frequent swimming in local ponds. On examination, you observe a pink, polypoid mass protruding from the right nostril, which bleeds easily upon touch. There is no significant lymphadenopathy. Histopathological examination of the mass reveals numerous thick-walled sporangia containing endospores. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidium Seeberi

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Cryptococcus neoformans is a cause of cryptococcosis , which most commonly affects the lungs and central nervous system , particularly in immunocompromised individuals . It does not cause nasal polypoid masses and is identified by its mucicarmine-positive capsule in histological sections, not by sporangia with endospores.
  • • Option B.
  • • cryptococcosis
  • • affects
  • • lungs
  • • central nervous system
  • • immunocompromised individuals
  • • Option C. While Staphylococcus aureus can cause various infections , including skin and soft tissue infections , it is not associated with the formation of polypoid masses in the nasal cavity that contain sporangia with endospores.
  • • Option C.
  • • various infections
  • • skin
  • • soft tissue infections
  • • Option D. Aspergillus fumigatus can cause aspergillosis , which includes conditions ranging from allergic reactions to invasive disease , especially in immunocompromised hosts . It primarily affects the respiratory system but does not produce the histopathological finding of sporangia containing endospores typical of rhinosporidiosis.
  • • Option D.
  • • aspergillosis
  • • ranging
  • • allergic reactions
  • • invasive disease
  • • immunocompromised hosts
  • • affects
  • • respiratory system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidium Seeberi is the causative agent of rhinosporidiosis , a disease characterized by polypoid masses in the nasal cavity or other mucosal sites , associated with exposure to stagnant water , and diagnosed by histopathology showing sporangia containing endospores .
  • ➤ causative agent
  • ➤ rhinosporidiosis
  • ➤ polypoid masses
  • ➤ nasal cavity
  • ➤ mucosal sites
  • ➤ exposure
  • ➤ stagnant water
  • ➤ diagnosed
  • ➤ histopathology
  • ➤ endospores
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, Pg 158
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, Pg 158

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of painless, gradually progressive reduction of vision of the right eye over several months. IOP was OD: 55mmHg and OS: 19mmHg. Anterior chamber was of normal depth in both eyes. A white flaky disc was seen on the anterior lens capsule after dilatation in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

This pigment can clog the trabecular meshwork , increasing intraocular pressure . Typical signs include mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects , dense pigmentation of the trabecular meshwork , and a Krukenberg spindle (a vertical deposition of pigment on the corneal endothelium ).

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes MacEwen’s triangle, a key surgical landmark in mastoid surgery?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus

options.label: C
options.text: It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

Ans. C) It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old music teacher presents with a complaint of progressive hoarseness over the last six months. She denies any respiratory infections, smoking, or other medical issues but mentions that her job requires extensive vocal use. On laryngoscopy, small bilateral lesions are observed at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vocal Nodules

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by HPV , leads to the development of multiple wart-like growths on the larynx . It is less likely given the patient's symptoms and the characteristic appearance of the lesions on laryngoscopy.
  • • Option A
  • • HPV
  • • development
  • • multiple wart-like growths
  • • larynx
  • • Option B. Vocal cord polyps are usually unilateral, peducnculated and may be associated with vocal abuse , but they tend to be larger and more vascular than nodules. The bilateral and small nature of the lesions in this patient is more indicative of vocal nodules. Site is junction of Anterior 1/3rd & Posterior 2/3rd of vocal cords.
  • • Option B.
  • • unilateral, peducnculated
  • • vocal abuse
  • • tend
  • • larger
  • • more vascular
  • • Option D. Reinke's edema is characterized by swelling of the vocal cords , usually related to smoking or other irritants. It does not present with small bilateral lesions at the junction of the vocal cords as described in this case.
  • • Option D.
  • • swelling
  • • vocal cords
  • • smoking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose vocal nodules in patients presenting with progressive hoarseness , especially in those with extensive vocal usage , and recognize their appearance as small bilateral lesions at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords on laryngoscopy . Vocal cord Nodules are Bilateral & Sessile. Also known as Screamer`s /Singer`s /Teacher`s nodule due to Prolonged Voice Abuse. Mx is Voice Rest & Speech therapy.
  • ➤ Diagnose vocal nodules
  • ➤ progressive hoarseness

  • ➤ laryngoscopy

  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 303

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient visited the ophthalmologist with complaints of Red, Watery Eyes with a slight gritty sensation since the past 10 days. After examination, he is diagnosed with Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis. Which Adenovirus Serotype is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 8 & 19.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Serotypes 10 & 12: These serotypes are not typically associated with epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Adenovirus serotypes 10 and 12 are more commonly associated with respiratory illnesses .
  • • Option A
  • • Serotypes 10 & 12:
  • • Adenovirus serotypes 10
  • • 12
  • • respiratory illnesses
  • • Option B. Serotypes 3 & 7: These serotypes can cause various adenoviral infections , including some forms of conjunctivitis, but they are not the most common causes of epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.
  • • Option B. Serotypes 3 & 7:
  • • adenoviral infections
  • • Option C. Serotypes 3 & 8: Serotype 3 is associated with a range of adenoviral infections , including conjunctivitis , but serotype 8 is one of the primary serotypes known to cause epidemic keratoconjunctivitis .
  • • Option C. Serotypes 3 & 8:
  • • adenoviral infections
  • • conjunctivitis
  • • primary serotypes
  • • epidemic keratoconjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotypes 8 & 19 of adenovirus are most frequently responsible for cases of epidemic keratoconjunctivitis , which is characterized by symptoms like red, watery eyes and a gritty sensation .

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to a pediatric ophthalmology clinic with enlarged and cloudy corneas, excessive tearing, and light sensitivity. Examination reveals increased intraocular pressure, corneal edema, and increased cup:disc ratio of the optic nerve head. The diagnosis of developmental glaucoma (congenital glaucoma) is made. All of the following drugs can be given to lower the IOP except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brimonidine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases aqueous humour production . It is generally considered safe and can be used in infants to lower IOP .
  • • Option A. Dorzolamide
  • • topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
  • • decreases aqueous humour production
  • • safe
  • • infants
  • • lower IOP
  • • Option B. Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue used to increase the outflow of aqueous humour , thereby lowering IOP . It is generally safe for use in infants , although monitoring for potential side effects like iris hyperpigmentation is important.
  • • Option B. Latanoprost,
  • • prostaglandin analogue
  • • increase
  • • outflow
  • • aqueous humour
  • • lowering IOP
  • • generally safe
  • • infants
  • • monitoring
  • • potential side effects
  • • Option D. Betaxolol is a beta-blocker used in glaucoma to reduce aqueous humour production . It is generally safe for use in infants , although, like all systemic beta-blockers , it requires monitoring for potential respiratory and cardiovascular effects .
  • • Option D. Betaxolol
  • • beta-blocker
  • • glaucoma
  • • reduce aqueous humour production
  • • generally safe
  • • infants
  • • all systemic beta-blockers
  • • requires monitoring
  • • potential respiratory
  • • cardiovascular effects

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Brimonidine , an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces aqueous humour production and increases uveoscleral outflow , is not recommended for use in infants and young children due to the risk of severe side effects , including respiratory problems , lethargy , and decreased heart rate . It is contraindicated in children under the age of 2 years .

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly explains the importance of phase differential between the oval and round windows in the auditory system?

options.label: A
options.text: Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration

options.label: B
options.text: Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window

options.label: D
options.text: Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

questions.correct_answer: D. Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phase differential between the oval and round windows ensures alternate compression and rarefaction, preventing cancellation of waves and enabling perilymph movement for effective hearing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.

questions.text: Which is the thickest wall of the orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lateral wall

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Medial Wall : The medial wall of the orbit is one of the thinnest and most fragile parts . It is formed primarily by the ethmoid bone and partly by the lacrimal bone , the frontal bone , and the lesser wing of the sphenoid. questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of hoarseness, dysphagia, and a persistent cough. Physical examination reveals a loud, high-pitched, rough systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ortner Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mitral Valve Prolapse (MVP) is unlikely to cause hoarseness, dysphagia, or a rough systolic murmur.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis typically presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur and is not associated with the characteristic symptoms of Ortner syndrome.
  • • Option B.
  • • crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur
  • • Option C. Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) can cause various cardiac symptoms , but it is not a common cause of hoarseness, dysphagia, or a rough systolic murmur.

  • • various cardiac symptoms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ortner syndrome, also known as cardiovocal syndrome , is characterized by hoarseness , dysphagia , and a persistent cough due to compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve by a cardiovascular structure , most commonly the aorta or left atrium . A rough systolic murmur is often heard in association with this condition. Therefore, the correct answer is D) Ortner syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of severe headache, fever, and double vision. She recently had a dental abscess treated. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, and her visual examination shows impaired lateral movement of the right eye. There is no ptosis or pupillary abnormality. Her facial sensation is intact. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows evidence suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which cranial nerve is most likely involved first in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Abducent

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Oculomotor (Cranial Nerve III) : This nerve controls most of the eye's movements , the constriction of the pupil , and maintains an open eyelid . In cavernous sinus thrombosis , its involvement typically results in ptosis (drooping eyelid), pupillary dilation, and limited eye movement except for lateral and downward gaze.
  • • Option A. Oculomotor (Cranial Nerve III)
  • • nerve controls most of the eye's movements
  • • constriction of the pupil
  • • maintains an open eyelid
  • • cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • • results in ptosis
  • • Option B. Trochlear (Cranial Nerve IV) : This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle , which is responsible for downward and lateral eye movement . Its involvement would lead to vertical diplopia, particularly when looking down.
  • • Option B. Trochlear (Cranial Nerve IV)
  • • nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle
  • • downward and lateral eye movement
  • • Option D. Trigeminal (Cranial Nerve V) : This nerve is responsible for facial sensation and motor functions of the muscles of mastication . Involvement in cavernous sinus thrombosis would cause facial sensory loss and chewing difficulties but not eye movement disorders.
  • • Option D. Trigeminal (Cranial Nerve V)
  • • nerve is responsible for facial sensation
  • • motor functions of the muscles of mastication

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cavernous sinus thrombosis , the abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) is typically the earliest to be affected due to its vulnerability within the cavernous sinus , often presenting with an inability to abduct the eye and resulting in horizontal diplopia .
  • ➤ cavernous sinus thrombosis

  • ➤ earliest to be affected due to its vulnerability
  • ➤ cavernous sinus
  • ➤ presenting

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came with the complaint of shortness of breath. On examination, fullness in the right supraclavicular region is observed. On ocular examination, right pupil is constricted. Which of the following is not a feature of the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heterochromia Iridis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ptosis: This is a hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a sympathetically innervated muscle in the eyelid, leading to a slight drooping of the upper eyelid.
  • • Option A. Ptosis:
  • • hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome.
  • • Option B. Anhidrosis: This refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face . It is a feature of Horner's syndrome due to the disruption of sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands.
  • • Option B. Anhidrosis:
  • • refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face
  • • Option D. Enophthalmos: This refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. While mild enophthalmos can be associated with Horner's syndrome due to the lack of sympathetic tone to the orbitalis muscle, it is not as prominent or diagnostic as the other features.
  • • Option D. Enophthalmos:
  • • refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance.
  • • Conclusion:
  • • Conclusion:
  • • Heterochromia iridis is not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos being a less prominent associated feature.
  • • Heterochromia iridis
  • • not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome.
  • • triad of Horner's syndrome
  • • ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of 5 days of progressive left facial swelling and fever. On ocular inspection, left periorbital oedema, erythema and discharge are noted. On examination, left eye showed decrease in visual acuity, and the pupil showed relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation) : This is an abnormal connection between arteries and veins , bypassing the capillary system . It can cause swelling and other issues due to altered blood flow , but it typically does not present with infection-like symptoms (fever, discharge) or a rapid onset of visual changes and RAPD.
  • • Option A.
  • • AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation)
  • • abnormal connection between arteries and veins
  • • bypassing the capillary system
  • • cause swelling
  • • altered blood flow
  • • does not present with infection-like symptoms
  • • Option C. Retinoblastoma : A malignant tumor of the retina , common in children . It usually presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may cause vision loss . However, retinoblastoma does not typically cause fever , periorbital edema, or erythema, which are indicative of an infectious process.
  • • Option C.
  • • Retinoblastoma
  • • malignant tumor of the retina
  • • children
  • • white pupillary reflex
  • • cause vision loss
  • • retinoblastoma
  • • not typically cause fever
  • • Option D. Neuroblastoma : A cancer that develops from immature nerve cells , mostly occurring in children . It can present with various symptoms depending on the site of the tumor but is unlikely to cause localized periorbital edema , erythema, and discharge without other systemic or neurological symptoms.
  • • Option D.
  • • Neuroblastoma
  • • cancer that develops from immature nerve cells
  • • children
  • • site of the tumor
  • • unlikely
  • • cause localized periorbital edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pediatric patient presenting with fever , progressive facial swelling , periorbital edema , erythema , discharge , decreased visual acuity , and RAPD , the most probable diagnosis is Orbital Cellulitis , an infectious condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the orbital tissues, often requiring prompt medical intervention.

  • • immune suppression

  • • Option B. Posterior Polar Cataract is located at the posterior pole of the lens and is often due to congenital posterior capsular dehiscence . It has a whirl like appearance .
  • • Option B. Posterior Polar Cataract
  • • posterior pole
  • • lens
  • • congenital posterior capsular dehiscence
  • • whirl like appearance
  • • Option C. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC) forms under the posterior capsule of the lens . This type of cataract is associated with several factors , including long-term use of corticosteroids , radiation , and intraocular inflammation .
  • • Option C. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract (PSC)
  • • posterior capsule
  • • lens
  • • cataract
  • • several factors
  • • long-term use
  • • corticosteroids
  • • radiation
  • • intraocular inflammation
  • • It has a “bread crump” appearance
  • • “bread crump” appearance
  • • Option D. Anterior Polar Cataract forms at the front pole of the lens and is often congenital . It's not typically associated with medication use like Amiodarone.
  • • Option D. Anterior Polar Cataract

questions.text: Identify the sign.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Krukenberg Spindle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pseudo-Exfoliation: The anterior lens capsule commonly exhibits a central disc with a peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material that shows radial indentations . These two components are separated by a clear zone , which is maintained through abrasion caused by the movement of the pupil .
  • • Option A. Pseudo-Exfoliation:
  • • anterior lens capsule
  • • exhibits
  • • central disc
  • • peripheral layer
  • • pseudoexfoliative material
  • • shows radial indentations
  • • clear zone
  • • maintained through abrasion
  • • movement
  • • pupil
  • • Option B. Sampaolesi Line: Refers to pigment deposits that can be observed on or anterior to the Schwalbe's line , particularly in heavily pigmented angles like seen in Pseudoexfoliation syndrome .
  • • Option B. Sampaolesi Line:
  • • pigment deposits
  • • observed
  • • anterior
  • • Schwalbe's line
  • • heavily pigmented angles
  • • Pseudoexfoliation syndrome
  • • Option C. Glaukomflecken: Refers to small , focal areas of anterior grey-white subcapsular or capsular opacities that develop within the pupillary area . These opacities are considered pathognomonic of previous episodes of acute congestive angle closure and represent focal infarcts of the lens epithelium .
  • • Option C. Glaukomflecken:
  • • small
  • • focal areas
  • • anterior grey-white subcapsular
  • • capsular opacities

questions.text: A patient undergoing perimetry has the following visual field defect. What is the pupillary abnormality expected in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wernicke’s pupil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Argyll Robertson Pupil: This is a condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light-near dissociation). They do, however, constrict with accommodation . It is classically associated with neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis, and does not have a direct correlation with homonymous hemianopia.
  • • Option A
  • • Argyll Robertson Pupil:
  • • condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict
  • • exposed to bright light
  • • constrict with accommodation
  • • Option B. Adie’s Pupil: Also known as tonic pupil , it is usually unilateral and is larger than the other pupil . It reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. This condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye and is not related to visual field defects.
  • • Option B.
  • • Adie’s Pupil:
  • • tonic pupil
  • • unilateral and is larger than the other pupil
  • • condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers
  • • Option C. Marcus Gunn Pupil: Also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), it is a sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction . It is detected using the swinging flashlight test . However, in homonymous hemianopia, the optic nerve function is typically preserved until the optic chiasm, so a Marcus Gunn pupil is not expected.
  • • Option C.
  • • Marcus Gunn Pupil:
  • • relative afferent pupillary defect
  • • sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction
  • • detected using the swinging flashlight test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case of right homonymous hemianopia , the lesion lies at the level of left optic tract , and the pupillary abnormality seen in these cases will be Wernicke’s pupil .
  • ➤ right homonymous hemianopia
  • ➤ lesion lies at the level of left optic tract
  • ➤ pupillary abnormality
  • ➤ Wernicke’s pupil
